content: Meet the requirements for being a nude model. Being a nude model doesn't require you to look like you're ready for the runway or to meet some unrealistic standard of beauty. Nude models help artists learn to draw the human body and understand its nuances and structure. Artists don't necessarily look for models who fit a stereotype and are open to models of all sizes, shapes, and ethnicities. People with unique body types and asymmetrical bodies are actually sought after. An important requirement for being a nude model is being comfortable with your body. [1] Before you model nude, you should be comfortable enough to pose nude without blushing, covering yourself up, or trying to only show off the most flattering parts of your body. Prepare a resume. Not every artist or art teacher will ask for a resume, but you should be prepared with one anyway. You can still fill your resume even if you haven't been a nude model before. Providing a resume will give the artist or art teacher an idea of who you are. This is important for getting to know you as modeling for an art class is an intimate setting for both the artist and model that requires trust. Include any previous modeling experience, performances, art schooling, acting, dance, yoga, or other activity you have done which would benefit an artist model. Find work as a nude art model. If you're committed to being a nude art model, then you need to start looking for work. Contact your local art school or college to see if they are hiring art models. You can start with the art department, but ask if there is someone in particular assigned to hire models for all classes. Sometimes each instructor hires his or her own models. If you want to pose for a photographer, also look on any one of a number of websites that link models to photographers. Free online classified advertising websites also often post ads for nude models. You should first find work modeling for a class and only consider doing some private modeling once you have a better understanding of the nude art modeling world and know that you're working with a legitimate artist. Discuss the details in advance. When you are hired, it is best to iron out payment, time commitment, and schedule. Typical nude art modeling sessions run about three hours, including a number of breaks and a variety of poses held for 5, 10, or 20 minutes. Discuss average length and number of poses, the types of poses, and the amount of breaks you'll be given. Discuss payment or hourly sitting rates, which can vary greatly but generally are between $15 and $25 for drawing -- though fees for a photographer will generally be higher. Prepare your poses. Nude art models are typically expected to strike four basic poses during their sessions. [2] These are standing, seated, reclining, and semi-reclining or prone. The standing pose requires you to stand in a variety of ways with your arms, legs, hands, and feet engaged in various ways. You might have props to hold or have to hold a particular facial expression. The reclining pose will typically require you to lie down on your back on a sofa or couch in a comfortable position. The semi-reclining pose will require you to lie down on your stomach while lifting your chest, as you would do to read a magazine at the beach. These are the four basic poses, but there is a variety of movements and gestures that you can make when you hold them. It is important to note that when in a standing pose, not to let your knees lockout (doing so may cause you to pass out). Be expressive. Draw on any personal experience to think of poses that are interesting or inspiring. Any physical activity may be a source of good poses. A good model must be able to be expressive from the bottoms of their feet to the tips of their fingers. Art is dynamic and your poses should be as well! [3] Many models are inspired by the poses depicted in classical works of art. Yoga poses are often used because they engage the muscles in interesting and dynamic ways. Be prepared to hold each pose for a specified amount of time. Different kinds of poses can be held for short or long periods. It is best to be prepared to hold still for a long time. [4] The time required for a pose can be described by any of the following three terms: gestures, short poses, and long poses. Gestures are poses lasting less than three minutes. Short poses last three to twenty minutes, and long poses which are held in multiple 20 minute intervals with a short break in between. The latter is generally the norm for painting and sculpture; drawing classes will require a number of shorter poses. Any class may begin with a few gestures as a "warm-up". If you're in the middle of a long pose and need to move, someone will use tape to mark the position of your body. Just ask, "Can someone please tape me?" Put together a "modeling bag. " You should come prepared to your modeling session so you don't need to trouble the artist by asking for anything and maintain your professionalism. The most important thing you need to bring is a robe so you can wear it between poses or to use the bathroom. You should also bring a towel or blanket to sit on for hygienic reasons. Bring slippers or sandals to slip in and out of quickly on breaks. You might also want to have water or snacks with you. Always bring a date book and pen (or your phone) for booking future sessions. Prepare your body. You will want to be clean and look natural. Before you leave for your session, shower and apply lotion to soothe dry skin, which could cause you discomfort while posing. Wear minimal jewelry unless otherwise requested. You shouldn't put in a ton of hairspray or wear make up unless requested. You should look as natural as possible. Remove your clothing. Once you meet the artist and get comfortable, it'll be time to remove your clothes. [5] A private changing room will likely be provided or there may be a folding screen that you can change behind. Use the privacy to get centered and ready for a nude art modeling session. Remove your clothes and put on your robe and slippers. Step up to the modeling area. Step up onto the model's area holding only your timer to mark the time passed in each of the posing sessions. Remove your robe and slippers. Your artist will designate an area for you to place these items during your session. If sitting or lying down, it is best to do so on a towel or sheet. The artist may provide one for you, or you can bring one of your own. If you do not have a towel, it is hygienic and highly recommended that you place your robe beneath your bottom for sitting poses. Some artists even enjoy drawing the additional "drapery." Follow the artist's directions. Keep your body and eyes very still. Listening to your artist is key for a successful session. [6] It is useful to fix your gaze on one spot; do not make eye contact with any artist unless specifically directed. Relax into the pose, but not so much that you move from your original position. You may be asked to time your own poses or the artist may tell you when you're finished. If you're not sure about what the artist means, don't be afraid to ask for clarification. This is far better than striking the wrong pose. If you're told to hold a pose that is too challenging, it's better to speak up than to try to hold it. The artist would rather have you hold a pose that you can maintain for the duration instead of having to start over. Get dressed. When you are finished with your session, put on your robe and return to your private changing area and put on your clothes. Make sure you don't leave anything in the studio. You should wear comfortable clothes. It is a good idea to have a bag for your dirty robe or towel so you can wash these after your session. Be prepared when you say goodbye to the artist. You will want to discuss any further sessions at this time. Have your date book and pen handy when you come out of the change room in case the artist would like to work with you again. It's also a good idea to prepare a business card to hand to the artist. Ask for feedback from the artist. Once you've worked with the artist a few times, you can even ask for a letter of recommendation that you can use to help you find future work. Follow up with your artist. You want to show initiative and enthusiasm if you want to be hired again. Call or email to confirm a time and date for your next session. If you don't book another session right away, contact the artist in a few weeks after your session to see if they need any more models. Ask your artist for other contacts if you have developed a good working relationship.

<p>Nude art models have been around since the days of ancient Greece and their work is both difficult and rewarding. If you want to be a nude art model, you have to be comfortable with your body, know how to hold a variety of poses, and understand the proper protocol. This article addresses the basics of getting hired, working, and posing for an artist.</p>

<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">

<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-1-Version-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=20813" href="#/Image:Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-1-Version-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">

<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Meet the requirements for being a nude model.</b> Being a nude model doesn't require you to look like you're ready for the runway or to meet some unrealistic standard of beauty.

<ul>
<li>Nude models help artists learn to draw the human body and understand its nuances and structure.</li>
<li>Artists don't necessarily look for models who fit a stereotype and are open to models of all sizes, shapes, and ethnicities. People with unique body types and asymmetrical bodies are actually sought after.</li>
<li>An important requirement for being a nude model is being comfortable with your body.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Before you model nude, you should be comfortable enough to pose nude without blushing, covering yourself up, or trying to only show off the most flattering parts of your body.</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>

<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Prepare a resume.</b> Not every artist or art teacher will ask for a resume, but you should be prepared with one anyway.

<ul>
<li>You can still fill your resume even if you haven't been a nude model before.</li>
<li>Providing a resume will give the artist or art teacher an idea of who you are. This is important for getting to know you as modeling for an art class is an intimate setting for both the artist and model that requires trust.</li>
<li>Include any previous modeling experience, performances, art schooling, acting, dance, yoga, or other activity you have done which would benefit an artist model.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>

<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Find work as a nude art model.</b> If you're committed to being a nude art model, then you need to start looking for work.

<ul>
<li>Contact your local art school or college to see if they are hiring art models.</li>
<li>You can start with the art department, but ask if there is someone in particular assigned to hire models for all classes. Sometimes each instructor hires his or her own models.</li>
<li>If you want to pose for a photographer, also look on any one of a number of websites that link models to photographers.</li>
<li>Free online classified advertising websites also often post ads for nude models.</li>
<li>You should first find work modeling for a class and only consider doing some private modeling once you have a better understanding of the nude art modeling world and know that you're working with a legitimate artist.</li>
</ul>

<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Discuss the details in advance.</b> When you are hired, it is best to iron out payment, time commitment, and schedule.

<ul>
<li>Typical nude art modeling sessions run about three hours, including a number of breaks and a variety of poses held for 5, 10, or 20 minutes.</li>
<li>Discuss average length and number of poses, the types of poses, and the amount of breaks you'll be given.</li>
<li>Discuss payment or hourly sitting rates, which can vary greatly but generally are between $15 and $25 for drawing -- though fees for a photographer will generally be higher.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>

<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Preparing_to_Pose">Preparing to Pose</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-5-Version-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=20813" href="#/Image:Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-5-Version-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Nude Art Model Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c2/Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-5-Version-4.jpg/aid20813-v4-728px-Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-5-Version-4.jpg" height="546" id="img_fc6cfc86d8" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_fc6cfc86d8')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Nude Art Model Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c2/Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-5-Version-4.jpg/aid20813-v4-728px-Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-5-Version-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Prepare your poses.</b> Nude art models are typically expected to strike four basic poses during their sessions. <sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>These are standing, seated, reclining, and semi-reclining or prone.</li>
<li>The standing pose requires you to stand in a variety of ways with your arms, legs, hands, and feet engaged in various ways. You might have props to hold or have to hold a particular facial expression.</li>
<li>The reclining pose will typically require you to lie down on your back on a sofa or couch in a comfortable position.</li>
<li>The semi-reclining pose will require you to lie down on your stomach while lifting your chest, as you would do to read a magazine at the beach.</li>
<li>These are the four basic poses, but there is a variety of movements and gestures that you can make when you hold them.</li>
<li>It is important to note that when in a standing pose, not to let your knees lockout (doing so may cause you to pass out).</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-6-Version-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=20813" href="#/Image:Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-6-Version-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Nude Art Model Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-6-Version-5.jpg/aid20813-v4-728px-Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-6-Version-5.jpg" height="546" id="img_1fa1d5b83d" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_1fa1d5b83d')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Nude Art Model Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-6-Version-5.jpg/aid20813-v4-728px-Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-6-Version-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Be expressive.</b> Draw on any personal experience to think of poses that are interesting or inspiring. Any physical activity may be a source of good poses.

<ul>
<li>A good model must be able to be expressive from the bottoms of their feet to the tips of their fingers. Art is dynamic and your poses should be as well! <sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Many models are inspired by the poses depicted in classical works of art.</li>
<li>Yoga poses are often used because they engage the muscles in interesting and dynamic ways.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-7-Version-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=20813" href="#/Image:Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-7-Version-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Nude Art Model Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0c/Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-7-Version-4.jpg/aid20813-v4-728px-Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-7-Version-4.jpg" height="546" id="img_729f325607" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_729f325607')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Nude Art Model Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0c/Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-7-Version-4.jpg/aid20813-v4-728px-Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-7-Version-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Be prepared to hold each pose for a specified amount of time.</b> Different kinds of poses can be held for short or long periods. It is best to be prepared to hold still for a long time. <sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>The time required for a pose can be described by any of the following three terms: gestures, short poses, and long poses.</li>
<li>Gestures are poses lasting less than three minutes.</li>
<li>Short poses last three to twenty minutes, and long poses which are held in multiple 20 minute intervals with a short break in between.</li>
<li>The latter is generally the norm for painting and sculpture; drawing classes will require a number of shorter poses.</li>
<li>Any class may begin with a few gestures as a "warm-up".</li>
<li>If you're in the middle of a long pose and need to move, someone will use tape to mark the position of your body. Just ask, "Can someone please tape me?"</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-8-Version-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=20813" href="#/Image:Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-8-Version-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Nude Art Model Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a7/Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-8-Version-5.jpg/aid20813-v4-728px-Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-8-Version-5.jpg" height="546" id="img_ed5772bea8" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ed5772bea8')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Nude Art Model Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a7/Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-8-Version-5.jpg/aid20813-v4-728px-Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-8-Version-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Put together a "modeling bag.</b>" You should come prepared to your modeling session so you don't need to trouble the artist by asking for anything and maintain your professionalism.

<ul>
<li>The most important thing you need to bring is a robe so you can wear it between poses or to use the bathroom.</li>
<li>You should also bring a towel or blanket to sit on for hygienic reasons.</li>
<li>Bring slippers or sandals to slip in and out of quickly on breaks.</li>
<li>You might also want to have water or snacks with you.</li>
<li>Always bring a date book and pen (or your phone) for booking future sessions.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-9-Version-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=20813" href="#/Image:Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-9-Version-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Nude Art Model Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-9-Version-5.jpg/aid20813-v4-728px-Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-9-Version-5.jpg" height="546" id="img_dab53f9f54" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_dab53f9f54')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Nude Art Model Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-9-Version-5.jpg/aid20813-v4-728px-Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-9-Version-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Prepare your body.</b> You will want to be clean and look natural.

<ul>
<li>Before you leave for your session, shower and apply lotion to soothe dry skin, which could cause you discomfort while posing.</li>
<li>Wear minimal jewelry unless otherwise requested.</li>
<li>You shouldn't put in a ton of hairspray or wear make up unless requested. You should look as natural as possible.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>

<div class="qz_header">
<p>Method 2 Quiz</p>
<p class="qz_question">If you're asked to do a gesture pose, what should you do?</p>
</div>
<form action="#" class="qz_form" target="_blank">
<div class="qz_section incorrect" id="quiz_2_0">

<p class="qz_explanation">Nope! A pose held between 3-20 minutes is known as a short pose. You'll likely be asked to do a number of these during your session, especially if you're posing for a sketching class. <span class="qz_addon">There’s a better option out there!</span></p>
</div>
<div class="qz_section incorrect" id="quiz_2_1">
<input class="qz_radio" id="radio_2_1" name="quiz_2" type="radio"/><label for="radio_2_1">Get into a natural and comfortable pose.</label>
<p class="qz_explanation">Not necessarily! Some of your gestures might be natural and comfortable, but this isn't the basic definition of a gesture. In preparation for your posing, you'll want to make sure you know the four basic poses you'll probably be asked to do: standing, seated, reclining, and semi-reclining. <span class="qz_addon">Click on another answer to find the right one...</span></p>
</div>
<div class="qz_section correct" id="quiz_2_2">
<input class="qz_radio" id="radio_2_2" name="quiz_2" type="radio"/><label for="radio_2_2">Hold a pose for less than three minutes.</label>
<p class="qz_explanation">Absolutely! A gesture is a short pose, held for under three minutes. Even if the bulk of your session will be made up of long and short poses, the class might ask you to start off with a series of gestures to help them warm up. <span class="qz_addon">Read on for another quiz question.</span></p>
</div>
<div class="qz_section incorrect" id="quiz_2_3">
<input class="qz_radio" id="radio_2_3" name="quiz_2" type="radio"/><label for="radio_2_3">Get into a pose with a prop.</label>
<p class="qz_explanation">Not quite! Props are often used in nude modeling, but you won't necessarily use props with gestures. You don't need to bring your own props or accessories – the class, teacher, or director will provide them for you if they want you to use or hold them.  <span class="qz_addon">Pick another answer!</span></p>
</div>
<div class="qz_section incorrect" id="quiz_2_4">
<input class="qz_radio" id="radio_2_4" name="quiz_2" type="radio"/><label for="radio_2_4">Use your hands to create a pose.</label>
<p class="qz_explanation">Not exactly! You should think about how your hands look in all of your poses—it's not more or less important to employ your hands in a gesture. Remember that your hands can be very expressive, so use them! <span class="qz_addon">Try again...</span></p>

<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-10-Version-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=20813" href="#/Image:Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-10-Version-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">

</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Nude Art Model Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/86/Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-10-Version-4.jpg/aid20813-v4-728px-Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-10-Version-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Remove your clothing.</b> Once you meet the artist and get comfortable, it'll be time to remove your clothes. <sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>A private changing room will likely be provided or there may be a folding screen that you can change behind.</li>
<li>Use the privacy to get centered and ready for a nude art modeling session. Remove your clothes and put on your robe and slippers.</li>
<li>Step up to the modeling area. Step up onto the model's area holding only your timer to mark the time passed in each of the posing sessions.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-11-Version-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=20813" href="#/Image:Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-11-Version-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Nude Art Model Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/02/Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-11-Version-4.jpg/aid20813-v4-728px-Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-11-Version-4.jpg" height="546" id="img_8496db377b" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_8496db377b')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Nude Art Model Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/02/Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-11-Version-4.jpg/aid20813-v4-728px-Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-11-Version-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Remove your robe and slippers.</b> Your artist will designate an area for you to place these items during your session.

<ul>
<li>If sitting or lying down, it is best to do so on a towel or sheet. The artist may provide one for you, or you can bring one of your own.</li>
<li>If you do not have a towel, it is hygienic and highly recommended that you place your robe beneath your bottom for sitting poses.</li>
<li>Some artists even enjoy drawing the additional "drapery."</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-12-Version-5.jpg?ajax=true&aid=20813" href="#/Image:Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-12-Version-5.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Nude Art Model Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6c/Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-12-Version-5.jpg/aid20813-v4-728px-Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-12-Version-5.jpg" height="546" id="img_411411ff0c" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_411411ff0c')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Nude Art Model Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6c/Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-12-Version-5.jpg/aid20813-v4-728px-Be-a-Nude-Art-Model-Step-12-Version-5.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Follow the artist's directions.</b> Keep your body and eyes very still. Listening to your artist is key for a successful session.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>It is useful to fix your gaze on one spot; do not make eye contact with any artist unless specifically directed.</li>
<li>Relax into the pose, but not so much that you move from your original position.</li>
<li>You may be asked to time your own poses or the artist may tell you when you're finished.</li>
<li>If you're not sure about what the artist means, don't be afraid to ask for clarification. This is far better than striking the wrong pose.</li>
<li>If you're told to hold a pose that is too challenging, it's better to speak up than to try to hold it.</li>
<li>The artist would rather have you hold a pose that you can maintain for the duration instead of having to start over.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
<a name="qz_anchor_1"></a>
<div class="qz_container qz_desktop" id="qz_container_1">
<div class="qz_score">Score<br/><span class="qz_numerator">0</span> / <span class="qz_denominator">0</span>
</div>
<div class="qz_header">
<p>Method 3 Quiz</p>
<p class="qz_question">What should you do if the artist asks you to strike a pose you can't hold?</p>
</div>
<form action="#" class="qz_form" target="_blank">
<div class="qz_section correct" id="quiz_1_0">
<input class="qz_radio" id="radio_1_0" name="quiz_1" type="radio"/><label for="radio_1_0">Ask them if they can change the pose.</label>
<p class="qz_explanation">Exactly! Be honest and open witth your artist. It is better that you tell them right away if you can't hold a pose—they'd rather slightly shift the pose than have you collapse or adjust halfway through. <span class="qz_addon">Read on for another quiz question.</span></p>
</div>
<div class="qz_section incorrect" id="quiz_1_1">
<input class="qz_radio" id="radio_1_1" name="quiz_1" type="radio"/><label for="radio_1_1">Do a slighlty different pose you can hold.</label>
<p class="qz_explanation">Try again! Don't change poses or positions without the artist's permission. They have a vision for what your poses should look like, so follow their directions to the best of your ability. <span class="qz_addon">Click on another answer to find the right one...</span></p>
</div>
<div class="qz_section incorrect" id="quiz_1_2">
<input class="qz_radio" id="radio_1_2" name="quiz_1" type="radio"/><label for="radio_1_2">Hold the pose for as long as you can.</label>
<p class="qz_explanation">Not necessarily! If you know that you're not going to be able to hold the pose for the requested amount of time, don't just try it and see how it goes. Don't be afraid to talk to your artist and ask questions as you're posing—that's better than falling in the middle of a session! <span class="qz_addon">Pick another answer!</span></p>
</div>
<div class="qz_section incorrect" id="quiz_1_3">
<input class="qz_radio" id="radio_1_3" name="quiz_1" type="radio"/><label for="radio_1_3">Slowly relax from the original pose into a pose you can hold.</label>
<p class="qz_explanation">Nope! Although you may think your movements are subtle, remember that there may be a whole class watching your every move! There is a better way to deal with this situation than to try and sneakily change positions. <span class="qz_addon">Click on another answer to find the right one...</span></p>

<ul>
<li>Have your date book and pen handy when you come out of the change room in case the artist would like to work with you again.</li>
<li>It's also a good idea to prepare a business card to hand to the artist.</li>
<li>Ask for feedback from the artist.</li>
<li>Once you've worked with the artist a few times, you can even ask for a letter of recommendation that you can use to help you find future work.</li>

<ul>
<li>Call or email to confirm a time and date for your next session.</li>
<li>If you don't book another session right away, contact the artist in a few weeks after your session to see if they need any more models.</li>
<li>Ask your artist for other contacts if you have developed a good working relationship.</li>
</ul>

<ul>
<li>Cell phone cameras have emerged as another problem. Institutions may have rules against them but models must be vigilant.</li>
<li>When responding to an advertisement, whether on the Internet or otherwise, find out as much as possible before accepting the job.</li>
<li>There is a chance that someone may request a photograph to use as a reference for completing a work outside of class. This would be up to you and require an additional payment (usually 2-3 times the standard art model rates).</li>
<li>Private sessions will be higher-paying; but bring the slight risk of sexual harassment, or worse. Take as much care as you think necessary.</li>

title: How to Be a Nude Art Model
content_html:
Meet the requirements for being a nude model. Being a nude model doesn't require you to look like you're ready for the runway or to meet some unrealistic standard of beauty.
  • Nude models help artists learn to draw the human body and understand its nuances and structure.
  • Artists don't necessarily look for models who fit a stereotype and are open to models of all sizes, shapes, and ethnicities. People with unique body types and asymmetrical bodies are actually sought after.
  • An important requirement for being a nude model is being comfortable with your body.[1]
  • Before you model nude, you should be comfortable enough to pose nude without blushing, covering yourself up, or trying to only show off the most flattering parts of your body.
Prepare a resume. Not every artist or art teacher will ask for a resume, but you should be prepared with one anyway.
  • You can still fill your resume even if you haven't been a nude model before.
  • Providing a resume will give the artist or art teacher an idea of who you are. This is important for getting to know you as modeling for an art class is an intimate setting for both the artist and model that requires trust.
  • Include any previous modeling experience, performances, art schooling, acting, dance, yoga, or other activity you have done which would benefit an artist model.
Find work as a nude art model. If you're committed to being a nude art model, then you need to start looking for work.
  • Contact your local art school or college to see if they are hiring art models.
  • You can start with the art department, but ask if there is someone in particular assigned to hire models for all classes. Sometimes each instructor hires his or her own models.
  • If you want to pose for a photographer, also look on any one of a number of websites that link models to photographers.
  • Free online classified advertising websites also often post ads for nude models.
  • You should first find work modeling for a class and only consider doing some private modeling once you have a better understanding of the nude art modeling world and know that you're working with a legitimate artist.
Discuss the details in advance. When you are hired, it is best to iron out payment, time commitment, and schedule.
  • Typical nude art modeling sessions run about three hours, including a number of breaks and a variety of poses held for 5, 10, or 20 minutes.
  • Discuss average length and number of poses, the types of poses, and the amount of breaks you'll be given.
  • Discuss payment or hourly sitting rates, which can vary greatly but generally are between $15 and $25 for drawing -- though fees for a photographer will generally be higher.
Prepare your poses. Nude art models are typically expected to strike four basic poses during their sessions. [2]
  • These are standing, seated, reclining, and semi-reclining or prone.
  • The standing pose requires you to stand in a variety of ways with your arms, legs, hands, and feet engaged in various ways. You might have props to hold or have to hold a particular facial expression.
  • The reclining pose will typically require you to lie down on your back on a sofa or couch in a comfortable position.
  • The semi-reclining pose will require you to lie down on your stomach while lifting your chest, as you would do to read a magazine at the beach.
  • These are the four basic poses, but there is a variety of movements and gestures that you can make when you hold them.
  • It is important to note that when in a standing pose, not to let your knees lockout (doing so may cause you to pass out).
Be expressive. Draw on any personal experience to think of poses that are interesting or inspiring. Any physical activity may be a source of good poses.
  • A good model must be able to be expressive from the bottoms of their feet to the tips of their fingers. Art is dynamic and your poses should be as well! [3]
  • Many models are inspired by the poses depicted in classical works of art.
  • Yoga poses are often used because they engage the muscles in interesting and dynamic ways.
Be prepared to hold each pose for a specified amount of time. Different kinds of poses can be held for short or long periods. It is best to be prepared to hold still for a long time. [4]
  • The time required for a pose can be described by any of the following three terms: gestures, short poses, and long poses.
  • Gestures are poses lasting less than three minutes.
  • Short poses last three to twenty minutes, and long poses which are held in multiple 20 minute intervals with a short break in between.
  • The latter is generally the norm for painting and sculpture; drawing classes will require a number of shorter poses.
  • Any class may begin with a few gestures as a "warm-up".
  • If you're in the middle of a long pose and need to move, someone will use tape to mark the position of your body. Just ask, "Can someone please tape me?"
Put together a "modeling bag." You should come prepared to your modeling session so you don't need to trouble the artist by asking for anything and maintain your professionalism.
  • The most important thing you need to bring is a robe so you can wear it between poses or to use the bathroom.
  • You should also bring a towel or blanket to sit on for hygienic reasons.
  • Bring slippers or sandals to slip in and out of quickly on breaks.
  • You might also want to have water or snacks with you.
  • Always bring a date book and pen (or your phone) for booking future sessions.
Prepare your body. You will want to be clean and look natural.
  • Before you leave for your session, shower and apply lotion to soothe dry skin, which could cause you discomfort while posing.
  • Wear minimal jewelry unless otherwise requested.
  • You shouldn't put in a ton of hairspray or wear make up unless requested. You should look as natural as possible.
Remove your clothing. Once you meet the artist and get comfortable, it'll be time to remove your clothes. [5]
  • A private changing room will likely be provided or there may be a folding screen that you can change behind.
  • Use the privacy to get centered and ready for a nude art modeling session. Remove your clothes and put on your robe and slippers.
  • Step up to the modeling area. Step up onto the model's area holding only your timer to mark the time passed in each of the posing sessions.
Remove your robe and slippers. Your artist will designate an area for you to place these items during your session.
  • If sitting or lying down, it is best to do so on a towel or sheet. The artist may provide one for you, or you can bring one of your own.
  • If you do not have a towel, it is hygienic and highly recommended that you place your robe beneath your bottom for sitting poses.
  • Some artists even enjoy drawing the additional "drapery."
Follow the artist's directions. Keep your body and eyes very still. Listening to your artist is key for a successful session.[6]
  • It is useful to fix your gaze on one spot; do not make eye contact with any artist unless specifically directed.
  • Relax into the pose, but not so much that you move from your original position.
  • You may be asked to time your own poses or the artist may tell you when you're finished.
  • If you're not sure about what the artist means, don't be afraid to ask for clarification. This is far better than striking the wrong pose.
  • If you're told to hold a pose that is too challenging, it's better to speak up than to try to hold it.
  • The artist would rather have you hold a pose that you can maintain for the duration instead of having to start over.
Get dressed. When you are finished with your session, put on your robe and return to your private changing area and put on your clothes.
  • Make sure you don't leave anything in the studio.
  • You should wear comfortable clothes.
  • It is a good idea to have a bag for your dirty robe or towel so you can wash these after your session.
Be prepared when you say goodbye to the artist. You will want to discuss any further sessions at this time.
  • Have your date book and pen handy when you come out of the change room in case the artist would like to work with you again.
  • It's also a good idea to prepare a business card to hand to the artist.
  • Ask for feedback from the artist.
  • Once you've worked with the artist a few times, you can even ask for a letter of recommendation that you can use to help you find future work.
Follow up with your artist. You want to show initiative and enthusiasm if you want to be hired again.
  • Call or email to confirm a time and date for your next session.
  • If you don't book another session right away, contact the artist in a few weeks after your session to see if they need any more models.
  • Ask your artist for other contacts if you have developed a good working relationship.
